I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Of the two billion financially excluded adults in the world, one billion live in Asia. Two-thirds 
of this population have a mobile phone.1 Advances in information and communication technology 
(ICT), especially mobile phones and telecommunication infrastructure, have opened opportunities 
beyond the traditional bank branch to reach previously underserved populations. Digitalization 
and new distribution channels have the potential to transform the financial industry to make it 
more inclusive, transparent, and efficient. In addition, digitalization will help the financial industry 
become more resilient in coping with an unprecedented situation like the spread of COVID-19 as 
it reduces  person-to-person  contact,  helping to curb contagion  and promoting more resilient 
businesses. Financial inclusion through financial institutions (FIs) has proven to have positive 
impacts on economic growth, poverty reduction, and inequality in the Asia-Pacific region.2 
 
2.  ADB  is  supporting  the  development  of  sound  digital  finance  ecosystems  through 
publications  and conferences,  as well as assisting  governments  to enable fair and effective 
regulations. ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) has also worked with its FI 
clients through technical assistance (TA) to develop or further enhance digital finance strategies 
and purchase tablets to enable credit officers to reach borrowers, including women, in remote 
areas, for instance. To complement the aforementioned enabling business environment activities 
and the sovereign work to pilot specific untested technologies with smaller non-bank financial 
institutions and fintechs,3 the proposed regional capacity TA will support capacity building and 
knowledge sharing among partner FIs ready for ADB funding through nonsovereign operations to 
adopt specific digital finance  solutions for financial inclusion in the context of their strategy, 
operations, and markets. In addition, digitalization would help the FI partner become more resilient 
in coping  with an unprecedented  situation  like the  spread  of COVID-19.  Firsthand  findings 
gathered from partner FIs adopting digital solutions will also help expand the industry knowledge 
on practical experiences about challenges and solutions adapted to the different local contexts of 
the Asia Pacific region. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Digital finance potential. Digital finance, especially supported by mobile technology, has 
the potential to provide access to financial services for one billion people in Asia, more than half 
of them women. It could increase the volume of loans extended to individuals and businesses by 
$1.2 trillion and allow governments to save $78 billion per year by reducing leakage in spending 
and tax revenue.4 FIs are expected to also benefit through the reduction of more than 50% in 
direct costs annually while sustainably increasing their balance sheets by as much as $2.85 trillion. 
The deep impact that digitalization is having and will have in the financial sector is becoming more 
evident. New players are emerging, tapping into these opportunities- younger, more flexible, and 
targeted financial technology companies (“fintechs”) that specialize in developing highly effective 
technology and which are creating alternative finance modalities for customers5 and, on the other

4.  Covid-19 Digital Transformation:  COVID-19  has accelerated  FIs’ strategic plans to 
adopt digital  channels  as the mainstream choice. As COVID-19 has spread, FIs have been 
encouraging people to use alternative options to local branches. Early adoption of digital solutions 
like remote on-boarding of new account holders, acceptance of digital currency, etc. would not 
only help increase financial inclusion but would also help deal with the impact of COVID-19 and 
future public health crises. Individuals at the bottom of the economic pyramid and micro, small 
and medium enterprises (MSMEs)  will be the hardest  hit by the crisis, and digitalization  will 
become an essential tool in providing financial assistance to the segment.  
 
5.  Role for traditional FIs. As fintech innovators and MNOs become more mainstream, their 
share  of  financial  services  is increasing.  However,  these  new  competitors  are  unlikely  to 
completely disintermediate traditional FIs in the near term. Money transfers and payments are the 
fintech technology most adopted (75% of adoption rate in 2019), followed by insurance (48%) 
savings and investments (34%), financial planning (29%) and borrowings (27%).7 In that context, 
fintech players are increasingly seeking to collaborate with other FIs, and not necessarily bypass 
them (in the retail space, the share of fintechs with B2B (business to business) offerings has 
increased from 34% in 2011 to 47% in 2016, while in corporate and investment banking, the share 
is as high as 66%.8 With established networks and already consolidated brands which enhance 
the trust factor identified as one of the key elements for success rolling-out digital financial 
innovations,9 traditional FIs have a role to play in the new digital landscape, to the extent they 
adopt technology-driven innovation to differentiate themselves and operate their business more 
efficiently. For financial services providers, the cost of offering customers digital services can be 
80% to 90% percent lower than using physical branches.10 This enables providers to serve many 
more customers profitably, with a broader set of products and at lower prices.  Women are 
expected to particularly benefit from the digitalization trend. A growing body of literature suggests 
that well designed digital finance products can accelerate women’s economic empowerment, give 
women  greater  control  over their  finances  and  financial  decision-making,  and  improve  the 
performance of women-owned businesses.11 Big data and alternative credit models, driven by 
tech adoption, can also open up new markets such as lower income segments for the traditional 
FIs.12 
 
6.  Challenges. While some countries in the Asia-Pacific region are leaders in ICT and digital 
finance, on average the region lags behind others in several important areas such as online 
purchases, electronic payments, mobile money, and mobile government transfers.13 Many FIs in 
the region have adopted new digital and mobile channels, but most of them are still not fully

Two-thirds of total budgets for emerging-market  banks are still spent on “running the bank”, 
instead of on the effort needed to digitalize banks.14 This data illustrates that the adoption of 
technology  in the finance  industry  is not challenge-free.  Challenges  are both  related to the 
business environment (i.e. lack of infrastructure and interoperability, regulatory issues, cultural 
and trust factors, lack of data connectivity, etc.) and bank specific (i.e. legacy issues, IT obsolete 
systems, etc.). Collaboration between traditional FIs and fintechs can also be a challenge. Big 
banks don’t always understand new technology and how to implement it; small fintech firms don’t 
understand how banks make their investment decisions and find the organizational hierarchies 
confusing and bureaucratic. With the proliferation of digital finance opportunities on offer, FIs need 
to make strategic decisions on where to focus their investments to deliver a stronger customer 
proposition  to reach more customers  at a lower cost.15 Furthermore,  the digital  gender gap 
remains evident, with an estimated 1.1 billion unconnected women in low- and middle-income 
economies in Asia Pacific. Digital literacy among many women is lower than among men as their 
access to training is limited in science, technology, and mathematics that could equip them for 
the industries that will thrive in the automation age.  Gender stereotypes  about women and 
technology are persistent, for instance in Jakarta, more than one-third of male respondents said 
that it was “their responsibility to restrict what women access on the Internet“16 and in India, one 
village in Uttar Pradesh implemented a 2,100-rupee fine for any girl using a mobile phone outside 
the home.17 
 
7.  Need for customization. While the digitalization trend is global, the key success factors 
to adopt financial technology are not. Each market has its own challenges, cultural nuances, 
infrastructure, regulation, and customer needs. For FIs to capture the opportunities from digital 
banking solutions without adding needless complexity and cost, they need to craft digital finance 
strategies adapted to their specific markets and needs. These strategies will have to consider 
factors such as: 
 
a.  A country’s existing infrastructure, for instance, in countries where a digital ID 
has already been rolled-out such as India, Indonesia, Bangladesh and Pakistan, financial 
institutions could leverage technologies such as biometrics, to overcome the lower levels 
of  literacy  among  excluded  groups  like  women.  In  countries  without  this  type  of 
infrastructure,  FIs  operating  in  remote  areas  should  still  rely  on  traditional  client 
identification  processes,  but enabled  with technology  such  as  cloud-based  solutions 
instead of paper-based client origination activities; 
 
b.  Local digital finance ecosystems, for instance, in countries where MNOs are 
willing to create partnerships and policy integration between the banking and telecom 
sectors, financial institutions can develop alternative credit scoring models using data 
derived from mobile phone use or utilizing alternative methods designed for women who 
do not have access to traditional credit assets or a credit history; 
 
c.  Customer segments, for instance, financial institutions operating in rural areas 
with  exposure  to  agriculture  could  partner  with  fintechs  specialized  in  weather  risk 
insurance  based on satellite  data, to ease climate change  resiliency and adaptation

becoming more and more digitized, cybersecurity, consumer protection, and data privacy 
and protection will need to fundamentally be at the forefront, especially in the financial 
services industry.  
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  overall  impact  of the TA  is aligned  with  Strategy  2030  which aims  to address 
remaining poverty and reduce inequalities, promote rural development, strengthen governance 
and  institutional  capacity,  and  accelerate  gender  equality  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  through 
innovation, knowledge sharing and digital transformation. The main impact will be an increase in 
financial  services to excluded  segments  that can access efficiently priced, relevant financial 
services that they would not have otherwise accessed through traditional distribution channels.  
 
9.  The outcome will be for ADB’s non-sovereign partner FIs adopting specialized digital 
finance solutions and technology to develop or enhance  and scale innovative products and 
models to reach financially excluded segments, and for other industry practitioners to have access 
to in-depth knowledge from first-hand experiences from FIs adopting technology. The TA also 
aims to improve the overall efficiency of the partner FIs by providing them options to not only 
automate the customer outreach but also automate supporting functions like risk management 
and financial reporting, for instance. In addition, digitalization will help the FI partner become more 
resilient in coping with an unprecedented situation like the spread of COVID-19. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Methodology 
 
10.  The goal of this TA is to help PSOD’s partner FIs identify effective digital finance strategies 
that would allow them to enhance their business to reach more financially excluded customers, 
especially  women,  in  a more  efficient  way,  and  to  disseminate  practical  knowledge  about 
successful models and practices. To do so, the TA will have two complementary components. 
For both the components, PSOD will prioritize FIs directly impacted by COVID-19. 
 
11.  Output 1: Digital finance assessments and roadmaps. The TA will fund digital finance 
diagnoses in up to five selected partner FIs, either at the time of investments or FIs in the existing

portfolio.  This  component  will  include  a  high-level  assessment  of  the  potential  digital 
enhancements that the FI could implement in the context of the existing infrastructure, customer 
segment and market environment. This component will also include the definition of a roadmap 
for implementation with timelines, budget, and identification  of the alternatives to source the 
technology (either in-house development or partnerships with fintechs or software providers). For 
that purpose, the consultant and project team will closely coordinate with ADB Ventures to source 
specific fintech technologies from the network and investee companies ADB Ventures is working 
with.  Under  this Output, the team  will also explore  ways that technology  can help  women 
overcome or circumvent some of the social and cultural barriers to women's financial inclusion.  
The assessments  for specific partner FIs will be complemented by the expertise of a gender 
specialist  who  will  accompany  the  IT  consultants  to identify  opportunities  to  enhance  FIs’ 
management information systems with the identification of existing gender digital financial gaps, 
collection  of  sex-disaggregated  data  and  recommendation  of  digital  finance  solutions  that 
particularly target their female clients.19 These assessments and roadmaps will serve three main 
objectives: i) allow FIs to take informed decisions on the investment needed to enhance their 
capabilities to reach more customers in a more technology efficient way; ii) serve as the basis for 
further discussions on potential use of ADB’s funding in technology enhancements; and iii) gather 
market in-depth knowledge on challenges and opportunities faced by FIs adopting and scaling-
up digital finance solutions.  
 
12.  The selection of partner FIs will follow the same criteria PSOD currently applies to its FI 
clients when providing debt, equity, or guarantees. These criteria include sound financial health, 
high integrity standards, strategic alignment with ADB’s financial inclusion development goals, 
proven track record of effectively delivering financial services to financially underserved segments 
of the population, and a plan to enhance their outreach through technology. The TA resources 
will only be available to partner FIs for which ADB is processing a funding proposal or are already 
part of PSOD’s portfolio, with priority for equity investees. Incentives  for successful follow-up 
implementation of the identified solutions will be aligned. The TA will be available for countries 
and partner FIs across the Asia-Pacific region that meet the above-described criteria. The partner 
FIs’ pipelines will be built from two main sources:  
 
a.  Under the “One-ADB” approach, FIs with which other departments at ADB already 
have an established relationship under digital finance complementary TAs. For instance, 
under the Mekong Business Initiative, SDCC’s launched a fintech challenge for Vietnam’s 
commercial banks to engage with fintechs.20 Under that initiative, banks such as BIDV, 
were able to develop relationships with fintechs. BIDV received a $300 million A/B loan 
from PSFI for SME financing with a focus on underserved rural areas and women-owned 
SMEs,21 which  will  be  further  complemented  with  the  digital  finance  assessments 
proposed under this TA to define the roadmap for implementation of such technology. 
Similarly,  leads  could also come from the pilot projects implemented  under  SDCC’s 
Finance Sector Group; and 
 
b.  PSFI’s  2020-2021  current  investment  pipeline in strategic  sectors  in inclusive 
finance that could be enhanced with digital technology in countries such as but not limited 
to Pakistan, Uzbekistan, Papua New Guinea, Bangladesh and India.

13.  Output 2: Implementation Support and Knowledge Sharing. The TA will also support 
up  to  three  selected  FI  partners  in  sourcing  and  implementing  the  digital  solution.  The 
implementation support will be on a need basis and it will be evaluated based on management’s 
ability and willingness to implement the solution.  
 
14.  While literature on the benefits of digital finance for financial inclusion is abundant, there 
is still  a gap  on  practical  lessons  learned  adopting  digital  solutions  for  financial  inclusion. 
Combining the copious publicly available studies on digital finance solutions with original content 
from  the above exercise, the TA will support  the production  and dissemination  of practical, 
applicable and candid knowledge for practitioners on the challenges and solutions available to 
FIs to adopt digital finance technology depending on their context of operations. The TA will fund 
up to three stories to showcase the actual need, implemented solution, challenges faced and 
benefits to the selected FI partners. The format of such stories will be multi-media (i.e. write-up, 
video, podcast) to increase the dissemination and outreach through different channels including 
social media. These knowledge products will also aim to help PSOD promote digital finance and 
solicit new partners.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, of which (i) $300,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-donor contribution), (ii) $200,000 will 
be financed  on a grant  basis  by ADB’s Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-income 
transfer) and (iii) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development 
Partnership Special Fund (FSDPSF22). Additionally, a total of $500,000 will be financed by partner 
FIs, by providing management time and in-kind resources to complement the TA consultants’ 
work.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  Execution and implementation of the TA will be undertaken by ADB, with PSOD as the 
focal point or by the selected partner FI. The TA can be delegated to a partner FI if they have 
adequate management capabilities and processes in place to successfully execute the TA. Each 
partner FI will provide ADB with a semi-annual report on all financial activity and milestones of 
the TA.  
 
17.  ADB will disburse the TA funds directly to each partner FI through an advance payment 
facility (APF), following ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). A financial management assessment will be conducted to determine if the 
partner  FI has adequate financial management  capacity and records keeping capabilities to 
manage APF.  
 
18.  The execution of the TA requires the selection of consultants.  ADB will monitor the 
selection and procurement steps, check that the use of funds complies with relevant ADB policies, 
and check that outputs for development effectiveness are on track. 
 
19.  Each partner FI and ADB will enter into a TA agreement that sets out the terms and 
conditions for the TA, including  the partner FI's responsibilities  in selecting, contracting, and

20.  For Output 1 and 2, the TA deliverable will be implemented with the help of an international

expertise) with proven experience in digital finance in the private sector of emerging markets. The 
consultant will also have specific experience in IT due diligence, strategies, product marketing 
and development, roadmaps, project management and solution implementation. The expertise of 
the international consultant will also be coupled with the work of a local consultant firm that would 
do  the  research  work  in  relation  to  the  market  environment,  local  ecosystem,  existing 
infrastructure, etc. Output 1 will require 18 person-months of international consultant services and 
18 person-months of local consultant services. Output 1 will be implemented over 24 months from 
the start date. Output 2 will require 24 person-months of international consultant services and  
24 person-months of local consultant services. Output 2 will be implemented over 36 months from 
the start date.

IV.  PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Promoting digital finance strategies among partner financial institutions, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

1.  Approve TA by July 2020. 
2.  Secure no-objection from the beneficiary countries as partner FIs are identified. 
3.  Select consultants August - September 2020  
4.  Close TA by 31 December 2025.

Output 2: Digital finance solution implementation for at three selected partner FIs 
2.1 At  least one  digital finance solution  implementation and  one  users’ assessment completed  by

2.2 At least two digital finance solution implementations and two users’ assessments completed by

2.3 Feature stories are delivered at the pace of the digital finance assessments in Output 1.1 and Output 
2.1. (December 2025) 
 
Output 3: Participation of women in STEM is encouraged

3.2 At least two traineeship programs implemented by December 2025

12  Appendix 3 
Terms of Reference for Consultants 
 
Digital Financial Services Expert/Firm 
 
Duration: retainer for 2 years, with underlying contracts for each specific assignment (underlying 
assignments are expected to last between 3 to 4 months or more based on the requirement). 
 
The  consultant  will  work  with  ADB’s  Private  Sector  Financial  Institutions  Division  and  in 
consultation with other ADB staff as required.  
 
Purpose of assignment 
 
The consultant will support ADB by doing assessments and developing strategies and projects 
that integrate cutting edge digital technology in ADB identified financial institutions (FI). The 
purpose of each assessment is to identify opportunities for the selected FI to digitally expand and 
enhance  their  businesses  to  reach  more  financially  excluded  or  underbanked  customers, 
especially women, in a more efficient way either through the introduction of new technology, 
products and services, and/or creation of new business models. The assignment will include 
production  and  dissemination  of  practical  and  applicable  knowledge  for  ADB 
clients/partners/employees  on the challenges  and solutions  available to FIs to adopt digital 
finance technology depending on their context of operations.  The consultant is expected to 
provide  substantive  technical  advice, identify  solutions  and create a roadmap  in the form of 
advisory services and documentation.  
 
Responsibilities 
 
Digital technology in financial services such as smartphones, tablets, and handheld devices are 
reshaping communications and are making financial services to people and businesses more 
affordable, accessible and appropriate than in the past. These technologies can help transform 
FIs in the way they offer products and services to their customers as well as in the way they 
operate their business.  Digital financial technology also has the potential to improve the lives of 
those who are financially and socially excluded. In recent years financial service providers have 
incorporated  new  technologies  and  innovations  that  bring  with them  different  benefits  and 
impacts: biometric recognition, artificial intelligence and robotic process automation can improve 
access to clients, help recognize risks, and improve customer experience. Cloud computing and 
distributed ledger technology can also help improve operational and cross border efficiencies. 
 
The consultant will: 
 
•  need to be a dynamic individual or firm who will work in close coordination with the heads 
of ICT/Digital teams, product, operations and relevant stakeholders of the identified FIs; 
•  focus on designing the future technological infrastructure, on creating a technology-related 
portfolio of work or roadmap, and on developing data driven strategies; 
•  map  out  the  areas  of  work  for  organizational  digital  transformation  and  change 
management; 
•  support customer centric potential projects where digital technology in financial services 
can be integrated with the objective to expand access to finance and to promote financial 
and social inclusion; 
•  support the design and implementation of technical assistance/pilot projects that integrate 
digital technology for financial services;

13 
•  identify legal and regulatory requirements, international  standards and government  or 
central bank support needed to facilitate adoption of digital financial services; 
•  identify needs for and strategies to deliver financial literacy and digital literacy;  
•  support in identifying best practice examples, guidelines, checklists;  
•  contribute to preparation of reports and other documentation as required; and  
•  identify strategic partnerships for pilot project implementation. 
 
Detailed tasks will include to: 
 
•  define a roadmap for implementation  with timelines, budget, and identification  of the 
alternatives to source the technology (either in-house development or partnerships with 
fintechs or software/technology providers); 
•  perform an in-depth assessment of the potential digital enhancements that the FI could 
implement in the context of the existing infrastructure, customer segment and market 
environment; 
•  identify opportunities to enhance FIs’ management information systems with the collection 
of sex-disaggregated  data and identification of digital finance solutions that particularly 
aim at women populations; 
•  assess  suitable  payment  technologies  and  systems  that  are  required  to  enable 
introduction of digital financial solutions in the location; 
•  identify needs for customer digital financial literacy/capability; 
•  identify needs for organizational capacity building to enhance skills on digital financial 
technologies to help manage the FIs digital transition; 
•  identify opportunities for new revenue streams and product development through the use 
of data;  
•  prepare a final report containing that detail results and recommendations going forward, 
including relevant case studies; and 
•  coordinate the implementation  of pilots based on roadmap recommendation  for each 
identified  FI,  including  drafting  the  Terms  of  Reference  of  the  sought  solution  in 
coordination with the FI, helping the FI run the procurement process, management of the 
implementation project and outsourced consultants, etc. 
 
Relevant Experience & Requirements 
 
•  A Master’s  degree in information  technology,  finance or relevant fields. Alternatively, 
university  degree  in  related  fields  combined  with  additional  relevant  professional 
experience can be considered. 
•  Minimum of 10 years’ experience in digital financial technologies including decentralized 
applications, distributed ledger technology, artificial intelligence, machine learning, cloud 
computing, robotic process automation and big data analytics. The expert should have  
(i) proven ability to discover customer needs and to design sustainable, holistic solutions 
that carefully considers the interactions between people (human centric design), process 
and  technology;  (ii)  demonstrated  experience  in  development  and  new  technology 
disruptions that are aimed at expanding access to finance to underserved and unbanked 
populations; (iii) proven ability to deliver and implement solutions using various delivery 
channels with extensive experience of deploying innovative mobile and agency banking 
solutions; (iv) documented experience in working in developing  economies; (v) proven 
experience  in leading organizations through digital transformation initiatives within the 
banking industry.

14 
•  Experience in working directly with institutional banks, digital banks, fintechs and a range 
of key stakeholders including the private sector, central banks, financial sector regulators, 
government and international donors in digital financial services. 
•  Adequate understanding of information security (technology risks and exposures) relating 
to the platforms associated with digital financial services. 
•  Proven capacity to work in a team and to deliver measurable outputs in a timely manner. 
•  Excellent written and verbal communication skills in English is required.
